Award.AwardTitle: Surface Stress Relaxation and Resulting Residual Stress in Glass: A New Mechanical Strengthening Mechanism of Glasses
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Glasses have many important applications because they are transparent, low cost, light-weight, and can be produced in large quantities and rapidly. They have one drawback: a lack of high mechanical strength. There are some methods to make glasses stronger such as rapid cooling called tempering which is used to make stronger window glasses or the ion-exchange method which is used to make stronger touch screen for smart phones. However, these methods are not applicable to all glasses and cannot be used, for example, to make stronger silica glass optical fibers. A new glass strengthening method, which can be used for all types of glasses, is explored.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Water vapor in the atmosphere can affect the glass surface characteristics. When a glass is subjected to a tensile stress below the critical stress which can break the glass, at an appropriate temperature below the glass transition temperature, some of the surface tensile stress is relaxed by the influence of moisture. When the applied tensile stress is removed, the surface of the glass acquires a residual compressive stress. The resulting glass sample is stronger than before, because a greater tensile stress is required, in order to overcome the generated surface compressive stress, to break the glass. By clarifying mechanism by which water promotes surface stress relaxation and controls the kinetics of surface residual stress generation, an optimum temperature, time, tensile stress, and moisture content can be chosen to produce high strength glasses. Specifically, the magnitude of a sub-micrometer thick surface residual stress in silica glass optical fiber, produced by heating under a tensile stress and water vapor, can be estimated by using both the bending of sliced fibers as well as FTIR reflection spectroscopy and the result compared with the measured mechanical strength of the fibers. Furthermore, the proposed mechanism of glass strengthening can explain some long-standing mysteries in glass science. For example, a crack in a glass can grow under a low tensile stress. However, when the glass was first subjected to a low tensile stress, one which does not cause crack growth, and then subjected to the original tensile stress, the crack does not grow. Apparently, the glass became stronger by a sub-critical tensile stress application, but no convincing explanation exists at the present. In this research two graduate students and two undergraduates are trained on this research topic which combines exploration of the science and technology of glasses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Glasses have many wonderful properties such as optical transparency, ability to be used at high temperatures, and recyclability. They are widely used in optical fibers which can carry phone calls and TV channels,  windows of automobiles and buildings, and screens of TV, computers, and smart phones. One perceived weakness of glasses is its low mechanical strength, but glasses can be made stronger by putting a compressive stress on the glass surface. Automobile window glass plates are made stronger by rapid cooling (tempering) and smart phone screens are made stronger by replacing small ions in the glass surface with large ions (ion-exchange). Tempering cannot be applied to small fibers and ion-exchange is not applicable to glasses without mobile ions such as silica glasses. We found a new method to make all glasses stronger including silica glass fibers as thin as a human hair. The method involves a new phenomenon, which we discovered some years ago: stress on the surface of glass relaxes faster than the inside of the glass. The process for strengthening involved pulling on fibers in tensile stress and heat treating them at low temperatures for a short time in air, e.g. the temperature which you would bake a pizza for only 60 s. The water in the air promotes relaxation of the surface of the glass. When the applied stress is removed at room temperature, the fiber acquires a high surface compressive stress and becomes stronger. This method was found applicable to silica glass and other oxide glasses.

There have been several well-known mysterious phenomena related to mechanical strength of glasses. It was found that these mysterious phenomena were caused by the fast surface stress relaxation. One example, called fatigue limit, will be explained here. Glass which is loaded to higher loads will break quickly, but glass loaded at lower loads will survive longer before failing. Since the glass appears to get tired by continuous loading, the phenomenon is known as static fatigue. In reality, under a constant tensile stress, glass in air exhibits a slow crack growth and when this crack becomes sufficiently long, the glass will break. Under a higher load, the crack grows faster and therefore, the glass breaks in a shorter time; under a lower load, the crack grows more slowly and the glass has a longer life time. When the load is reduced sufficiently, the glass would not break and this limiting load which causes no breakage of the glass is called fatigue limit. Many people attempted to explain this fatigue limit phenomenon but no clear-cut explanation was possible. We explained this fatigue limit by surface stress relaxation. Under a low enough tensile stress, the crack growth will slow down because the surface stress relaxation will diminish the applied tensile stress. When the surface stress relaxation rate dominates compared with the crack growth rate, glass will never break. This model successfully explained the observed diminishing crack growth and its eventual stoppage under a constant applied load.

Two graduate students earned their Ph. D. conducting research on the relationship between surface stress relaxation and the mechanical strength of glasses. Through this research they experienced the pleasure of developing new strengthening method and solving a long-standing mysteries related to glass strength. They are now members of technical group of a US glass industry. This NSF sponsored program was very successful one with both faculty members and graduate students experiencing the pleasure of discovering new phenomenon and solving long-standing mysteries related to mechanical properties of glasses.
